tree.title: Louisiana Expungement Application (LEA) - Desktop
tree.description: This app will help you determine whether or not you can get your criminal conviction expunged under Louisiana law. If you are likely eligible for an expungement, you will find resources for pro bono and private attorneys who can assist you.
tree.disclaimer: This app does not provide legal advice. Any information which you give here is not confidential and is not protected by attorney-client privilege. This tool is for educational purposes only and intended to provide you with a better understanding of your options regarding your criminal record.

branch.content: Are you seeking an expungement for an offense for which you were arrested and prosecuted in Louisiana?

Many parishes require information in records to process an expungement. Contact the parish clerk of criminal court or {{an attorney}} where you were processed to find out whether the Court requires your records and on how you should proceed.
Do you have a copy of your criminal record? If you have a record of your case, such as the minutes, this will help you to answer this series of questions.
It is not possible to expunge a record for an offense that was outside of Louisiana. {{Contact an attorney}} in the city in which you were processed for more information and how to proceed.
Were you convicted or did you plead guilty after your arrest?
How did the prosecution against you end?
Were you convicted of a felony or misdemeanor?
It is likely that you are eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} on how to proceed.

Which of the following sentences describes the sentence for the offense for which you were arrested? See La. Code Crim. Pro. art 571, 571.1, 572, 573.
If you do not understand these phrases, review the statute for which you were arrested as a guide at http://hueylaw. org/site/index.php
branch.fork: A) Necessarily punishable by a term of imprisonment at hard labor.
B) Punishable by a term of imprisonment by a term with or without hard labor
C) Punishable by a fine or imprisonment

branch.content: An arrest that did not result in a conviction typically ends when a District Attorney refuses to prosecute and does not file a Bill of Information against you, the District Attorney dismisses all charges before trial, a judge or jury acquits a defendant, or when a Motion to Quash is successful. {{Seek the advice of an attorney}} to help you understand what may apply to you.
It is likely that you are eligible for an expungement six (6) years from the date of the offense. {{Contact an attorney}} to determine whether you should proceed before that time.
It is likely that you are eligible for an expungement four (4) years from the date of the offense. {{Contact an attorney}} to determine whether you should proceed before that time.
It is likely that you are eligible for an expungement two (2) years from the date of the offense. {{Contact an attorney}} to determine whether you should proceed before that time.
It is likely that you are eligible for an expungement six (6) months from the date of the offense. {{Contact an attorney}} to determine whether you should proceed before that time.
It is likely that you are eligible for an expungement thirty (30) years from the date of the offense. {{Contact an attorney}} to determine whether you should proceed before that time.
Was a true bill filed against you?
Typically, offenses for which there is no time limit for the District Attorney to file charges are ineligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} to determine whether this applies to you.
It may be possible to have your record expunged. Seek the advise of a licensed attorney to review your case.
Did your charge arise out of a domestic violence arrest?
Were you convicted of one of these crimes (a crime of violence under La. Rev. Stat. Ann. 14:2?)
Were you sentenced to probation?
Did your conviction arise out of an arrest that involved a sexual act?

Some offenses that involved a sexual act, such as those involving children, may not be expunged. {{Contact an attorney}} to find out whether there is an opportunity for you to overcome this provision.
Were you sentenced to probation?
Did you successfully complete probation? (Your probation was NOT revoked.)
It may be possible to seal your record from public view five (5) years after the completion of your sentence. {{Contact an attorney}} to find out more.
You are likely eligible for an expungement if your probationary sentence was deferred. {{Contact an attorney}} to review the details of the sentencing in your case.
It may be possible to seal your record from public view five (5) years after the completion of your sentence. {{Contact an attorney}} to review your options.
Did you successfully complete the terms of your probation? (Your probation was NOT revoked.)

At this time, you are not likely eligible for an expungement until five (5) years has passed from the date you completed your sentence. {{Contact an attorney}} for more details on expungement and destruction of your record.

Your eligibility for an expungement will depend on whether the time period has passed during which the prosecution can charge you. {{Contact an attorney}} for more information on whether that time period has passed or find out more information on the offenses below.
Did the Diversion program arise from a Driving Under the Influence (DUI) arrest?
It is likely you are eligible for an expungement thirty (30) years from the date of the offense. {{Contact an attorney}} to find out when it is best for you to proceed with an expungement.
Was a True Bill filed against you?

When a prosecution has been initiated following a True Bill, there is no time limit to institute formal proceedings. It is likely that you are not eligible for an expungement. {{Consult an attorney}} to review your case.
When a prosecution has failed to secure a True Bill, it may be possible to seal your record from public view. {{Consult an attorney}} to review your case.

Defendants who participate in a Diversion program arising out of a DUI offense are ineligible for an expungement for five (5) years from the date of your arrest. {{See an attorney}} to determine whether you may be eligible for an expungement following completion of Diversion for a DUI offense.
You are likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} to review the details of your case.
You are likely eligible for an expungement if your probationary sentence was deferred. {{Contact an attorney}} to review the details of the sentencing in your case.
At this time, you are likely ineligible for an expungement until five (5) years has passed from the date you completed your sentence. {{Contact an attorney}} for more details.
Crimes of violence are ineligible for deferred sentences, which is required for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to find out more information.
Are or were you required to register as a sex offender because you were convicted of one of these offenses?
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
Did the offense involve a child under the age of 17?
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
Were you convicted of distribution or the attempted distribution of a controlled dangerous substance?
Was the charge pursuant to La. Rev. Stat. Ann. 40:976(A), which includes but is not limited to distribution of methamphetamine or cocaine?
Were you convicted before 1995?
It may be possible to expunge this record. To be eligible for an expungement, the defendant MUST meet ALL requirements set forth under La. Rev. Stat. Ann. 44:9(E)(1)(c)
Were you convicted before 1995?
Seek the advice of a licensed attorney to advise you on ex post facto considerations.
Was this your first felony conviction anywhere in the country?
Were you given probation?
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
Did you successfully complete the terms of your probation? (Your probation was NOT revoked.)
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
You are likely eligible for an expungement if your probationary sentence was deferred. {{Contact an attorney}} to review the details of the sentencing in your case.
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
{{Contact an attorney}} because the procedure that is currently required for expungements did not exist before 1995.
Was the conviction your first felony conviction anywhere in the country?
Were you sentenced to probation?
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
Did you successfully complete the terms of your probation? (Your probation was NOT revoked.)
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
You are likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} to learn more.
You are not likely eligible for an expungement. {{Contact an attorney}} with questions or to learn more.
